title: Red-Eyed Tree Frog Enclosure Setup Guide
description: Complete guide to setting up a proper paludarium habitat for Red-Eyed Tree Frogs, including size requirements, vertical layout design, water section, and naturalistic décor.
excerpt: Complete guide to setting up a proper paludarium habitat for Red-Eyed Tree Frogs, including size requirements, vertical layout design, water section, and naturalistic décor.

content.heading: Why Paludarium Setup Matters
content.text: Red-Eyed Tree Frogs (Agalychnis callidryas) are semi-aquatic arboreal amphibians that require a specialized enclosure called a paludarium - a habitat combining both substantial water and vertical climbing space. Unlike standard terrariums, paludariums recreate the riparian zones (interfaces between land and water) where these frogs naturally live near ponds and streams in tropical rainforests. The paludarium design supports their dual lifestyle: climbing and sleeping on foliage during the day, then descending to water for hydration, thermoregulation, and breeding at night.

Red-Eyed Tree Frogs need vertical space for climbing combined with a substantial water section. The height-to-floor-space ratio is critical - these frogs spend most of their time in the upper canopy layers, not on the ground.
Prioritize HEIGHT over floor space. An 18×18×36″ enclosure is better than a 24×24×24″ cube for arboreal species.
Never place paludariums near windows with direct sunlight - can cause fatal overheating despite water cooling effects.
A functional paludarium divides into three zones that recreate natural rainforest stream edges:

items: Aquatic Zone (bottom 2-6 inches): Open water section for soaking, hydration, and breeding. Minimum 2″ depth for juveniles, 4-6″ for adults planning to breed. Water should be 25-30% of total enclosure volume.

Riparian Zone (land-water interface): Gently sloped transition area with easy access points. Use flat stones, driftwood ramps, or Cork Bark positioned to allow frogs to enter/exit water safely. Partially submerged plants like Anubias or Java Fern work well here.

Terrestrial/Arboreal Zone (upper 60-80%): Dense climbing network of branches, vines, cork bark positioned diagonally from bottom to top. Must include foliage layers at multiple heights with sturdy leaves (Pothos, Philodendron, Monstera) for daytime sleeping spots.

content.text: The riparian zone is CRITICAL - frogs must easily transition between water and climbing areas without stress or risk of drowning.
Paludariums require a false bottom drainage system to separate the water section from the terrestrial substrate and prevent waterlogging:

items: Layer 1 - Aquatic Bottom: Use large Turtle Pebbles (too large to swallow) or leave bare glass in the water section for easy cleaning.
Layer 2 - Bio Drain Substrate: Lightweight volcanic drainage media (1-2″ layer) in terrestrial zone only. Supports land area and houses beneficial bacteria for biological filtration.
Layer 3 - Bio Drain Mesh: Separates drainage layer from planting substrate. Prevents soil contamination of water while allowing drainage.
Layer 4 - Planting Mix: 2-3″ of Sub Stratum + Plantation Soil (60:40 ratio) for live plants. Holds moisture without waterlogging.
Layer 5 - Leaf Litter/Moss: Top with Equatorial Forest Floor or Forest Moss for moisture retention, hiding spots, and microfauna habitat.

content.text: Without proper drainage, terrestrial substrate becomes anaerobic and toxic. The Bio Drain system is mandatory for long-term paludarium health.
Red-Eyed Tree Frogs need 80-90% of vertical wall space covered with climbing pathways:

items: Diagonal Branches: Position branches at 30-60° angles from bottom to top, creating highways to climb. Use natural hardwood branches (avoid resinous woods) or cork bark tubes.
Vines & Lianas: Add bendable Jungle Vines or Moss Vines to fill gaps and create 3D climbing networks. Twist multiple vines together for structural complexity.
Cork Bark Panels: Attach flat Cork Bark pieces to back and side walls to expand climbable surface area. Also creates hiding spaces behind bark.
Live Plant Vines: Pothos (Epipremnum), Philodendron, and Scindapsus provide natural climbing routes and large leaves for sleeping spots. Train vines to grow across entire enclosure.

content.text: Frogs should be able to travel from water level to top of enclosure using only branches/vines without touching glass walls.
Red-Eyed Tree Frogs sleep on the UNDERSIDE of large leaves during the day, tucked tight with eyes closed for camouflage. Proper foliage is non-negotiable:
Always rinse new plants thoroughly and quarantine 7-14 days to remove pesticide residues and pests before introducing to frog enclosure.
The aquatic zone serves multiple functions beyond decoration - it's essential for hydration, thermoregulation, and breeding behavior:

items: Water Depth: 2-3″ for juveniles/non-breeding setups, 4-6″ for adults planning breeding (females need depth to absorb water into bladder for egg jelly).
Water Volume: Aim for 25-30% of total enclosure volume in water. Larger volume = more stable parameters and less frequent changes.
Circulation: Use a small submersible filter or waterfall pump for gentle circulation. Prevents stagnation and supports beneficial bacteria colonies.
Temperature: Maintain water at 78-79°F (25-26°C) using preset Turtle Heaters. Slightly cooler than ambient air temp is ideal.
Treatment: ALWAYS treat tap water with Aquatize to remove chlorine, chloramines, and heavy metals. Add Turtle Clean to boost beneficial organisms.
Access Points: Ensure 2-3 easy entry/exit locations using sloped stones, driftwood ramps, or partially submerged Cork Bark.

content.text: Water quality directly impacts frog health - they absorb through skin. Bi-weekly partial water changes (25-33%) are mandatory.
Despite needing high humidity, Red-Eyed Tree Frogs MUST have excellent airflow to prevent bacterial skin infections:

items: Full stainless steel screen top mandatory (never glass or solid plastic top)
Dual ventilation preferred: full screen top + ventilation strip on back/sides
Natural upward airflow from bottom vents to top screen
Prevents condensation buildup that causes respiratory/skin infections
DO NOT block ventilation to boost humidity - use misting frequency instead

content.text: Never keep humidity constantly above 75% even if frogs tolerate brief 90% peaks. Stagnant high humidity = bacterial infections.
Beyond functional climbing structures, add enrichment elements:

items: Canopy Cave or Cork Bark Hides: Provide 2-3 shaded retreat areas at mid/upper levels for stressed frogs
Frog Pond or Aztec Water Dish: Naturalistic water dish design if building minimalist water section
Waterfall or Cascade: Adds oxygenation, biological filtration, and visual/auditory enrichment (use low-flow pumps)
Floating Plants: Water Hyacinth, Duckweed, or Frogbit provide shade over water and egg-laying surfaces for breeding
Background Texturing: Apply silicone + coco fiber to back wall for naturalistic appearance and additional climbing surface
Plan Layout: Sketch where water section, land section, and climbing branches will go before adding substrate.
Install Drainage: Add 1-2″ Bio Drain Substrate to terrestrial zone only (not under water). Lay Bio Drain Mesh over top, cutting around water section.
Add Aquatic Substrate: Place Turtle Pebbles or leave bare glass in water section for easy cleaning.
Position Hardscape: Arrange large branches, Cork Bark panels, and stones to create climbing framework and riparian access points. Use silicone to secure if needed.
Add Planting Substrate: Top terrestrial zone with 2-3″ Sub Stratum + Plantation Soil mix. Slope away from water section.
Install Water Equipment: Position heater and filter/pump in water section. Hide with stones or driftwood. Connect drainage system if using drain valve.
Plant Live Plants: Install plants in substrate or in concealed pots. Create foliage density at multiple heights (low, mid, canopy).
Add Vines & Finishing: Weave Jungle Vines through branches. Add top layer of Forest Moss or leaf litter. Install floating plants in water.
Fill Water Section: Add dechlorinated water to desired depth (2-6″). Add Aquatize and Turtle Clean.
Cycle Setup: Run filtration and heating for 1-2 weeks before adding frogs to establish beneficial bacteria colonies.
Test Parameters: Use thermometers and hygrometer to verify temperature gradient (75-85°F) and humidity (70-75%) are within range.

content.text: NEVER add frogs until water has cycled for at least 1 week and temperature/humidity are stable within target ranges.

rows: Check water temperature, mist 2x (morning/evening), spot-check frogs during evening activity
Spot-clean feces, dead insects, fallen leaves from land and water sections
Test water quality (ammonia, nitrite, nitrate if cycled system), top off evaporated water
Partial water change (25-33%), clean filter intake/media, check equipment function
Deep clean water section (gravel vacuum), trim overgrown plants, inspect climbing structures
Replace substrate if showing signs of degradation or foul odor, replace filter media

content.text: NEVER do full water changes - removes beneficial bacteria. Partial changes only unless emergency (ammonia spike, disease).

items: Insufficient Height: Using standard terrariums instead of tall paludariums - frogs stressed without vertical climbing space
No Drainage System: Waterlogging terrestrial substrate without Bio Drain layer - causes anaerobic soil and root rot
Poor Water Access: Steep walls into water with no ramps - frogs struggle to exit, risk drowning from exhaustion
Inadequate Foliage: Sparse planting with no large leaves - frogs have nowhere to sleep, constantly exposed and stressed
Blocked Ventilation: Covering screen top with towels/plastic to boost humidity - causes respiratory infections
Overcrowding: Too many frogs in small space - territorial aggression, poor breeding success, disease spread
Direct Sunlight Placement: Near windows - causes fatal temperature spikes even with water cooling
Untreated Tap Water: Chlorine/chloramines burn frog skin - always use Aquatize
No Cycling Period: Adding frogs immediately - ammonia spikes from uncycled water cause chemical burns
Horizontal Emphasis: Using wide, short enclosures - wasted floor space frogs don't use

content.text: If starting with limited budget, prioritize these essentials and upgrade later:

rows: 18×18×36″ terrarium, Bio Drain system, branches, Pothos plants, spray bottle, thermometer/hygrometer
Automated misting, waterfalls, expensive live plants
Turtle heater, small filter, Aquatize, Cork Bark, additional live plants
Monsoon misting system, decorative water features, rare plant species, background texturing
These add aesthetics/convenience but aren't mandatory for frog health

content.text: You CAN build a functional paludarium for under $200-250, but expect to invest $400-600 for a well-equipped, low-maintenance setup.
